thread.title: Hockey: Black Sticks lose but take heart gain from match
thread.title_full: Hockey: Black Sticks lose but take heart gain from match

title: Hockey: Black Sticks lose but take heart gain from match
text:
Hockey 
Australia won the early skirmish, but New Zealand's eyes are on the main event at the Oceania Cup. 
The world No1 Australians beat the Black Sticks 3-1 in their men's round-robin clash in Stratford yesterday but there was not much in it. 
The teams will meet again on Sunday afternoon in a match world No7 New Zealand must win to advance to next year's Rio Olympic Games. 
Lose, and it will be the first Olympics the Black Sticks have missed since 2000, and likely cost a large chunk of funding too. 
Australia got off to a rollicking start yesterday with a goal inside the first minute by veteran striker Jamie Dwyer. 
It was pretty even from then on. It was not until nine minutes from the end that Tom Craig increased the lead with an overhead deflection. 
Striker Hugo Inglis closed the gap with a goal from a sharp angle five minutes from the end before Glenn Turner's late goal regained the two-goal margin. 
Nick Wilson and Ryan Archibald both went close for the Black Sticks, who felt it had been a good hit-out. 
New Zealand certainly held some cards up its sleeve before Sunday's match but believed it had gained much. 
Fiji thumped Samoa 20-0 in the other men's game, while Australia's women belted their Samoan opponents 25-0. 
The women's Black Sticks, ranked fourth in the world, had a day off yesterday as they prepare for back-to-back games against second-ranked Australia tomorrow and Sunday. Both those sides have qualified for Rio, so their matches will be more about pride than absolute necessity. 
- David Leggat
